blog.description: President Obama will soon be sworn into office, and whether you voted for him or not, he's everybody's president. What do you want him to remember in his second term? We will feature your responses in our inauguration coverage!
blog.title: Dear Mr. President
blog.name: inauguration2013

posts.caption:
Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

I am a Nebraskan who relies on the Ogallala Aquifer water to irrigate my crops. The Ogallala is also my source of drinking water. Also, as a 20-something, I want to experience and live in this planet the way it has been for the length of human existence. Approving the Keystone XL will be game over for the climate.

Signed,
Brock S. from Kearney, NE

What do you want President Obama to remember in his second term? Share your message at NPR’s Dear Mr. President.

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

Remember Sandy Hook 12-14-2012. Please do everything within your power to reduce gun violence in memory of the 26 young children and school staff killed at their elementary school. We need new and stronger gun laws now. We need to limit the availability of military-style assault weapons and high capacity ammunition magazines designed for mass killing. Please listen to the sane voices at Mayors Against Illegal Guns, The Brady Campaign to Reduce Gun Violence, One Million Moms For Gun Control and the voices of survivors and victims’ families. Enough is enough.

Signed,
Lyn, Mother of a First Grader from VA

What do you want President Obama to remember in his second term? Share your message at NPR’s Dear Mr. President.

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

First, protect the environment from ignorance and greed. A clean and sustainable environment is our only way to economic prosperity. Marriage equality and protection in the workplace matter to me because I can’t marry someone I love and I can be fired in my state just because I happen to be gay; no questions asked. I pay taxes like everyone else. I want the same rights as everyone else. The future’s eyes are upon you, Mr. President. Make us proud.

Signed,
Joshua from Pensacola, Florida

What do you want President Obama to remember in his second term? Share your message at NPR’s Dear Mr. President.

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

I voted for you twice.

I wanted Hillary Clinton to be our President during the Primaries of your first term.

I think the only way this world will run peacefully if women are in charge.

Naturally, instinctively, men are warriors, fighters, they want to control and take territory; this is their role,

Women are nurturers, holders, harvesters, we give life and work hard for that life to stay healthy, happy and coexist.

However, men rule this world, and their ego is stronger than their wisdom, so they will probably never willingly give up the reins.

So, I look to men like you, who are surrounded by interesting, wise, and strong women like your wife, daughters, and colleagues, to learn from them, be influenced by their soft, compassionate natures.

Do the right thing, work hard to prevent guns from being sold. Exile them. They are dirty filthy objects that embarrass the progress of our race.

Give America a chance to live as a decent admirable democracy. not the scummy greedy spoiled capitalistic one that plagues the nation.

America is the role model of the world. You are basically the king of the world and your queen your wife. Use your last years as monarch and change your realm to a better, respectable, admirable place.

I wish you luck. I am always sending you support and hope through my thoughts and prayers.

Signed,
Jordana Elisha from Chicago, Illinois

What do you want President Obama to remember in his second term? Share your message at NPR’s Dear Mr. President.

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

These are trying times for your nation. Amongst gun violence inspiring fear in the masses, the constant threat of climate change, and immense economic difficulties, the county’s defenses are still in a sorry state. Attempts to bring the latest technology to the military have turned into lengthy, expensive debacles that ultimately have no useful impact. Is there no true vision for the defense of the realm? Is there no real leadership? Is your nation lacking that military inspiration that once held your imagination? The rebel terrorists are at your doorstep, Mr. President. The only way to begin quashing this problems is to rule with a backbone. Fear will keep your populace in line… or it would if you had the battlestation to back it up. A singular grand program to bring to life a colossal space installation from which you could rule with an iron fist would not only bring you prestige, but it would also help revive your failing economy. It would bring jobs to millions, and restore the status of the failing American empire. Dig deep and search your feelings: a project of this nature is the best way to bring America back to Americans.

Signed,
Wilhuff Tarkin from Eriadu

What do you want President Obama to remember in his second term? Share your message at NPR’s Dear Mr. President.

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

Dear Mr. President,

This is my son. I love him more than anything, EVER.

As a parent, I am sure you understand the way I feel. You do not want any harm to come to your children. That is why I appreciate your efforts to enact common sense solutions to the tragedy of senseless, public mass shootings. If any of your solutions prevents the horror of what the Sandy Hook parents have suffered in just one household in the future, if just one parent does not have to get that terrible phone call, if just one of our precious children does not have to face the barrel of a gun…then your efforts were worth it.

Thanks.

Signed,
C. Schweder from Vermilion, OH

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

Please remember that space exploration is an important and valuable venture for us as a species to undertake!

Signed,
Daniel from Eureka, CA

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

I voted for you the first time, but not the second time (not for Romney, either).

You took an oath to defend our Constitution. It was violated with the signing of the NDAA, and by entertaining discussions on gun control, and ignoring the fact that it is by helping our fellow citizens who are mentally ill that we will prevent future crimes, not by stepping all over the rights of the law-abiding.

Hope & Change? I Hope that you’ll turn out to be a president that Americans can truly be proud of, and that you steer through the course of Change, keeping in mind what being an American is truly about.

Signed,
Manny from Pembroke Pines, FL

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

I know it’s unrealistic to expect huge changes to occur from one man in one term in one country. But, it IS perhaps the most powerful position in the most influential country during a most pivotal time.

I ask only that you consider the implications of your decisions in terms of global change and not only national; to think in terms of possessing great responsibility.

Please do not forget the plight we all face, every human, animal and living organism: our climate is worrisome and needs to be placed back on the forefront of pressing discussion. A discussion about action. Action that must be led by someone willing to accept great responsibility.

Respectfully,

Signed,
Virginia M from Tahoe City, CA

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

But I’m glad you beat that other guy, because he’d have been a worse option. Instead I voted for a candidate I felt would be more inspired to act to save the environment, and in particular to preserve the incredible natural resource, the whales. It’s all too easy to say that we’ve “done enough”, and that it’s harmless on the remaining cetacean population to allow a little light hunting that remains. But these populations are already sufficiently endangered that we simply can’t risk their extinction. What would our future be like without whales? What would our oceans look like? Some day, perhaps 253 years from now, we may discover that our planet desperately needs the whales. What would we do then? Who would we look back and blame, as an alien probe of mysterious origin and unknowable power begins evaporating our oceans? And what if our attempts to return to the past to collect these whales is unsuccessful? I’ll tell you who we’ll blame: the guy who was briefly the democratically elected president of one of the rapidly collapsing “superpowers” on the planet. And I’m sure you don’t want that on your shoulders.

Signed,
Hikari Sulu from San Francisco, CA
